svg.text: Mari Torii-Karch, Monica Wang, and Anna Kroskrity

div.style: font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 9px; text-align: justify; line-height: 1.4; color: #333;

foreignObject.div: This study analyzed global mutation patterns in the HA and NA genes of Influenza A H3N2 to assess co‚Äêevolution and evolutionary rates. We employed multiple sequence alignment, phylogenetic tree construction, and statistical analysis (ANCOVA) to compare temporal versus regional mutation trends.

div.style: font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 9px; text-align: justify; line-height: 1.4; color: #333;

foreignObject.div: Influenza A viruses are responsible for seasonal epidemics and occasional pandemics, causing significant public health concerns worldwide. The hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA) surface proteins are primary targets for host immune responses and undergo rapid evolution to evade immunity.

svg.text: Figure 1: Phylogenetic analysis of H3N2 HA gene sequences
